text: Do you maintain an up-to-date list of all company devices (laptops, phones, servers, tablets)?
Do you maintain a list of approved software that is allowed on business devices?
Is sensitive data (e.g. customer, financial, HR data) identified and labelled (for example: public, internal, confidential)?
Is multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled for all remote access and business email accounts?
Are default passwords on devices, routers and accounts changed before use?
Do workstations and mobile devices automatically lock after a short period of inactivity (for example, 5–10 minutes)?
Are administrator (admin) privileges restricted to only those who absolutely need them?
Is a firewall enabled on all laptops/desktops and at the network/router level?
Are operating systems and software set to automatically install security updates and patches?
Do all company devices have reputable antivirus or endpoint protection installed and kept up to date?
Is full-disk encryption enabled on laptops and mobile devices that store business data?
Is there a separate guest Wi-Fi network that is isolated from your main business network?
Do you have a simple, written incident response plan that explains what to do and who does what if there is a cyber incident?
Do you maintain a list of key emergency contacts (IT support, cloud providers, bank, legal or cyber support)?
Do you back up important business data (e.g. customer, financial, operational data) at least weekly?
Have you successfully tested restoring data from a backup in the last 6–12 months?
Do staff receive basic cybersecurity awareness training when they start and at least once per year?
Is there a process to immediately remove access (accounts, email, systems) when an employee or contractor leaves?
Do you check the security practices of third-party vendors before sharing sensitive data with them?
Do you have a documented process to handle privacy or data breaches in line with Australian privacy obligations?
